# Opportunities with CERN {#cern}

Did you know that CERN employs **ten times more engineers** and technicians than research physicists, see figure \@ref(fig:cern3-fig). For physicists to understand the data that pours off the [Large Hadron Collider](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_Hadron_Collider) (LHC), you need armies of engineers to enable the scientists to do their work. A *lot* of those engineers are working on hardware and software, and most of them won't be physicists. [@hullcern]

```{r cern3-fig, echo = FALSE, fig.align = "center", out.width = "100%", fig.cap = "(ref:captioncern)"}
knitr::include_graphics("images/cern-engineering.jpeg")
```

Whether you're an aspiring engineer, physicist, or developer, this programme will provide you with unparalleled exposure to cutting-edge technology and the chance to work alongside top experts in your field.

##  Next deadline 23rd Feb 2026

CERN has several rounds of applications every year for year-long placements (what they call `technical studentships`) in engineering and allied disciplines. The next deadline for applications is 23rd Feb 2026.

* For computing, mathematics & robotics see [bit.ly/cern-2026-compute](https://bit.ly/cern-2026-compute)
* For mechanical engineering see [bit.ly/cern-2026-mech](https://bit.ly/cern-2026-mech)
* For civil and general engineering see [bit.ly/cern-2026-civ](https://bit.ly/cern-2026-civ)
* For eletrical and electronic engineering see [bit.ly/cern-2026-eee](https://bit.ly/cern-2026-eee)
* For materials and surface science see [bit.ly/cern-2026-mat](https://bit.ly/cern-2026-mat)


If you missed the webinar in January with Ben Purchase (current technical student), Emma Quinn (current graduate) and Freddie Neill (recruiter) at CERN, a recording can be found at [gradcracker.com/webinars/170/start-your-journey-at-cern-in-geneva](https://www.gradcracker.com/webinars/170/start-your-journey-at-cern-in-geneva)
